comments: a(n) = Number of Galois Fields GF(k) with 2n elements. - _Artur Jasinski_, Oct 13 2011
references: Albert H. Beiler, "Recreations in the Theory of Numbers, The Queen of Mathematics Entertains," Second Edition, Dover Publications, Inc., NY, 1966, page 90.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..5000
Carl Pomerance, Popular values of Euler's function, Mathematica 27 (1980), 84-89.
example: If n=8 then phi(x)=2*8=16 is satisfied for only a(8)=6 values of x, viz. 17, 32, 34, 40, 48, 60.For 2n=16 we have 6 different of Galois Fields GF(k) with 16 elements : GF(17), GF(32), GF(34), GF(40), GF(48), GF(60). - _Artur Jasinski_, Oct 13 2011
author: Ursula Gagelmann (gagelmann(AT)altavista.net)
